message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Adaptive Prescribed-Time Control for a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems
Paper Abstract: This article focuses on the problem of prescribed-time control for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems. First, a prescribed-time stability theorem is proposed by following the adaptive technology for the first time. Based on this theorem, a new state feedback control strategy is put forward by using the backstepping method for high-order nonlinear systems with unknown parameters to ensure the prescribed-time convergence. Moreover, the prescribed-time controller is obtained in the form of continuous time-varying feedback, which can render all system states converge to zero within the prescribed time. It should be noted that the prescribed time is independent of system initial conditions, which means that the prescribed time can be set arbitrarily within the physical limitations. Finally, two simulation examples are provided to illustrate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Control reversal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reversal"},{"title":"Take back control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Take_Back_Control"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

Here are the search results for "Backstepping control":

## Overview

Backstepping is a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## How It Works

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, and the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized.(no content)Because this strict-feedback system has a feedback-stabilizing control and a corresponding Lyapunov function, it can be cascaded as part of a larger strict-feedback system, and this procedure can be repeated to find the surrounding feedback-stabilizing control.

## Applications and Context

Backstepping is among techniques like feedback linearization and sliding mode control that take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory for controlling nonlinear systems.

## Historical Development

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Category:Nonlinear systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Nonlinear_systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear system identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system_identification"},{"title":"Non-Linear Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Linear_Systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Linear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_system"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_stability"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Limit cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limit_cycle"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of nonlinear systems:

## Definition

A nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle. More technically, a nonlinear system is a system that does not satisfy the superposition principle, or any problem where the variable(s) to solve for cannot be written as a linear sum of independent components.

## Characteristics and Properties

## Real-World Applications

Nonlinear control theory applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.

## Analysis and Solutions

Problems involving nonlinear differential equations are extremely diverse, and methods of solution or analysis are problem dependent.(no content)The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, including limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

## Chaotic Behavior

Simple nonlinear dynamical systems can exhibit strongly unpredictable behavior, which might seem to be random despite being fundamentally deterministic, and this unpredictable behavior has been called chaos.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Here are the search results for "Adaptive control":

## Main Concept

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Technical Foundation

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Main Categories

There are several broad categories of feedback adaptive control including: Dual adaptive controllers based on dual control theory, Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) which incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance, and Model identification adaptive controllers (MIACs) which perform system identification while the system is running.

## Modern Applications

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control. Additionally, a particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Links: [{"title":"Full state feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_state_feedback"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Ackermann's formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackermann's_formula"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of state feedback control:

## Definition

State feedback control, or full state feedback (FSF), is also known as pole placement—a method employed in feedback control system theory to place the closed-loop poles of a plant in predetermined locations in the s-plane.

## Key Purpose and Advantages

Placing poles is desirable because the location of the poles corresponds directly to the eigenvalues of the system, which control the characteristics of the response of the system.(no content)A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## Fundamental Requirement

The system must be considered controllable in order to implement this method.(no content)Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval.

## State Feedback Implementation

In state feedback control, the eigenvalues of A can be controlled by setting K appropriately through eigendecomposition. The feedback gains are calculated to achieve desired system performance by forcing the closed-loop eigenvalues to specified pole locations.

## Related Approaches

The LQR algorithm is essentially an automated way of finding an appropriate state-feedback controller. As such, it is not uncommon for control engineers to prefer alternative methods, like full state feedback, also known as pole placement, in which there is a clearer relationship between controller parameters and controller behavior.

Based on the search results, here's information about finite-time convergence control:

## Finite-Time Convergence in Control Systems

The concept of finite-time convergence in control comes from terminal attractors, which guarantee finite time convergence of the states. This is particularly relevant in the context of **terminal sliding mode (TSM)** control.

### Terminal Sliding Mode Control

Terminal sliding mode (TSM) is a robust non-linear control approach that was invented in the early 1990s at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory by Venkataraman and Gulati.(no content)Unlike normal sliding mode control, which only promises asymptotic stability and convergence that may be guaranteed only within infinite time, TSM provides a different approach.(no content)In TSM, a nonlinear term is introduced in the sliding surface design so that the manifold is formulated as an attractor, and after the sliding surface is intercepted, the trajectory converges to the origin following a power rule.

### Key Advantage

The main advantage of finite-time convergence control approaches like TSM is that they guarantee convergence to a desired state in finite time, rather than only asymptotically approaching it over infinite time. This is particularly valuable in practical applications where reaching a target state quickly and predictably is important.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Lyapunov stability:

## Overview

Near a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable, the system remains stable under small disturbances. More formally, Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough.

## Related Concepts

There are several types of Lyapunov stability:

- **Asymptotic Stability**: Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

- **Lyapunov Functions**: Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.

## Historical Background

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Applications

During the Cold War period, the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities. More recently, the concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper on "Adaptive Prescribed-Time Control for a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems." Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes novel methods and theorems)

**Key Entities Extracted (6 triples):**

1. **Adaptive control** (uses) - Method used to develop the prescribed-time stability theorem
2. **Backstepping** (uses) - Method employed for designing the state feedback control strategy
3. **Nonlinear system** (uses) - The problem domain being addressed
4. **Full state feedback** (uses) - Core control strategy for achieving convergence
5. **Control theory** (uses) - Foundational field applying control principles
6. **Lyapunov stability** (proposes) - Novel prescribed-time stability theorem based on Lyapunov methods

All entities are correctly linked to their Wikipedia articles, and the JSON file has been validated successfully with no errors.

Sources:
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Backstepping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping)
- [Nonlinear system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system)
- [Full state feedback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_state_feedback)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Lyapunov stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability)
